Article.ArticleTitle: Drivers of ozone-related premature mortality in China: Implications for historical and future scenarios.

AbstractText: Long-term exposure to ambient ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) poses a severe public health threat in China. However, the drivers of premature mortality caused by O<sub>3</sub> pollution are still poorly constrained, despite being prerequisites for addressing the threat. Here, we demonstrate the contributions of historical and future changes in peak-season O<sub>3</sub>, population size, age structure, and baseline mortality to China's O<sub>3</sub>-related mortality using decomposition analysis. From 2013 to 2021, O<sub>3</sub>-related mortality decreased dramatically from 78.8 (40.8-124.6) to 68.7 (36.0-107.2) thousand, especially in densely populated areas with high pollution. Variations in peak-season O<sub>3</sub>, population size, age structure, and baseline mortality led to changes in O<sub>3</sub>-related mortality of +27.3 (14.8-41.3), +2.6 (1.4-4.1), +22.3 (11.5-35.2), and -40.3 (20.9-63.7) thousand, respectively. The influence of peak-season O<sub>3</sub> on O<sub>3</sub>-related mortality shifted from positive during 2013-2019 (+8.4% per year) to negative during 2019-2021 (-8.8% per year), which highly regulated the interannual trend of mortality. From 2021 to 2035, O<sub>3</sub>-related mortality is expected to increase by 31% in the current context of peak-season O<sub>3</sub> levels, primarily caused by increased aging. Even reducing peak-season O<sub>3</sub> to the WHO interim target 1 (IT-1) would only reduce O<sub>3</sub>-related mortality by 3.9%, while a more rigorous standard (IT-2) would prevent 83.7% of mortality. These findings suggest that improving ambient O<sub>3</sub> can lead to significant health benefits, but substantial mitigation strategies are merited given the future trend of population aging.
